properties.location: Black Snake Creek, Blomford, Budgee Budgee, Castleburn, Cobbannah, Cowa, Crooked River, Dargo, Gibbs, Grant, Hawkhurst, Hogtown, Howittville, Hunter Corner, Maguires, Miowera, Moornapa, Moroka, Naarun, Peter the Swede, Selwyn, Shepherdson, Talbotville, Toolome, Treasure, Treasures, Waterford, Winchester, Wongungarra, Wonnangatta, Woolenook, Abbeyard, Arbuckle, Billabong, Briagolong, Glenaladale, Howitt Plains, Iguana Creek, Valencia Creek, Wrathung
properties.webBody:
This Watch and Act message is being issued for Abbeyard, Arbuckle, Billabong, Black Snake Creek, Blomford, Briagolong, Budgee Budgee, Castleburn, Cobbannah, Cowa, Crooked River, Dargo, Gibbs, Glenaladale, Grant, Hawkhurst, Hogtown, Howitt Plains, Howittville, Hunter Corner, Iguana Creek, Maguires, Miowera, Moornapa, Moroka, Naarun, Peter the Swede, Selwyn, Shepherdson, Talbotville, Toolome, Treasure, Treasures, Valencia Creek, Waterford, Winchester, Wongungarra, Wonnangatta, Woolenook, Wrathung.
  • There is a bushfire at Mt Darling - Cynthia Range (Dargo - Wonnangatta Complex) that is not yet under control.
  • Weather conditions have changed, fire spread has slowed but is still active. 
  • Emergency Services, Machinery and Aircraft are operating in the area and are working on supressing the fire edges and building control lines. 
  • This Watch and Act replaces the Watch and Act issued at 12:50pm Sunday 11th January.
The situation can change at any time. You must monitor conditions and be ready to act.
What you should do: 
  • Monitor changes to the situation. Increased wind speed, change in wind direction, smoke or poor visibility can indicate the situation is changing. 
  • Enact your fire survival plan. 
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes. 
  • If you have time, check your neighbours to see if they are monitoring conditions. 
  • Protect yourself and your family.
Leave if the situation changes or you feel unsafe. 
Remember to:
  • Take your pets, medications, mobile phone and charger. 
  • Many people have died trying to leave at the last minute during fires. 
  • Travel to the home of family or friends that are away from the warning area.
Impacts in your area:

The following roads are restricted to residents and property owners only. Access will be permitted for essential maintenance and animal care. Proof of ownership is required and must be provided via Driver’s Licence or Rates Notice. 
  • Bairnsdale-Dargo Road at the Beverleys Road Junction 
  • Freestone Creek Road at Coopers Road   

The following roads are closed: 
  • Dargo High Plain Road between Dargo and Great Alpine Road 
  • Marathon Road at the Moroka Road Junction 
  • Marathon Rad at the Boundary 24 Track Junction   

The following Parks/Areas are closed to the public:  
  • Blue Pool on Freestone Creek Road is Closed   
  • The Alpine National Park north of Briagolong, East of Arbuckle Junction and Mount Howitt, west of Dargo including the Wonnangatta, and south of Abbeyard, west of the Great Alpine Rd to Lake Cobbler is Closed.  
  • The Mitchell River National Park is Closed 

  • Emergency Services are operating in the area.  
  • Smoke will be visible from nearby communities and roads. 
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 12/01/2026 01:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires) 
  • ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
  • https://www.parks.vic.gov.au/places-to-see/parks/alpine-national-park#change-of-conditions
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • For information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.webBody:
This Watch and Act message is being issued for Carranballac, Stoneleigh and the rural area of Skipton. 
  • This grassfire is now contained.
  • However, it is Not Safe to Return to Carranballac, Stoneleigh and the rural area of Skipton. 
  • Hazardous trees and fallen powerlines, pose a significant risk to residents attempting to return home.
  • A hazardous tree assessment team is working to re-open roads.
  • Powercor are on scene assessing and repairing critical infrastructure with significant progress made today. 
If you left Carranballac, Streatham and the rural area of Skipton, it is Not Safe to Return.

Be aware of potential dangerous bushfire and tree hazards.
What you should do:

If you have not already left: 
  • Stay where you are and avoid dangerous bushfire and tree hazards.
  • Check you have enough food, drinking water and medications - if you do not, phone Triple Zero (000) for assistance.
If you have already left: 
  • Do not return to your home until a Safe to Return notification is issued.
  • A recovery centre is open at the Beaufort Community Resource Centre, 72 Neill Street, Beaufort from 10am to 5pm.
  • A recovery hub is open at the Skipton Mechanics Hall, 5 Anderson Street, Skipton from 10am to 4pm.
Community Meetings:
Community meetings will be held on Tuesday, 13 January 2026 at the below locations:
  • 12pm at Beaufort Community Bank Complex (17 Lawrence Street, Beaufort)
  • 2pm at Streatham Memorial Hall (30 Campbell Street, Streatham)
  • 4pm at Skipton Mechanics Hall (5 Anderson Street, Skipton)
Powercor Mobile Emergency Response Vehicle:
  • Representatives will be at Skipton Mechanics Hall on Monday, 12 January 2026 from 10am with the Mobile Emergency Response Vehicle. 
  • This is an opportunity for the community to talk to Powercor about power supply and it has capacity to charge up to 20 mobile devices.  

Road closures have changed:
  • The Glenelg Highway is closed between: Eurambeen-Streatham Road, Streatham and Pittong-Lismore Road, Skipton. 
  • Eurambeen-Streatham Road at Richies Road
  • Mt William Road at Beaufort-Carranballac Road
  • Lismore-Skipton Road at Leydens Lane
  • Vite-Vite Skipton Road at Walkers Road
  • 4km South of Darlington-Carranballac Road
  • Check the VicTraffic website (www.traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.
This message was issued by Country Fire Authority. 

The next update is expected by 12/01/2026 09:00 am or as the situation changes. 

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires)
  • ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV. 
Accessibility: 
  • The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.webBody:
This Watch and Act message is being issued for Barongarook West, Irrewillipe, Irrewillipe East, Tomahawk Creek.
  • There is a bushfire at Carlisle River that is not yet under control.
  •  The bushfire is travelling from Trotters Lane, Carlisle River in a north-westerly direction towards Bungador.
  • Firefighters have been able to slow the spread of fire for now, but the situation can change at any time. You must monitor conditions and be ready to act.
  • There will be noticeable ground and aircraft activity overnight. 
  • This Watch and Act replaces the Watch and Act issued at 9:54pm. 
The situation can change at any time. You must monitor conditions and be ready to act.
What you should do: 
  • Monitor changes to the situation. Increased wind speed, change in wind direction, smoke or poor visibility can indicate the situation is changing. 
  • Enact your fire survival plan. 
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes. 
  • If you have time, check your neighbours to see if they are monitoring conditions. 
  • Protect yourself and your family.
Leave if the situation changes or you feel unsafe. 
Remember to:
  • Take your pets, medications, mobile phone and charger. 
  • Many people have died trying to leave at the last minute during fires. 
  • Travel to the home of family or friends that are away from the warning area.
Impacts in your area:
The following roads are  closed:
  • Carlisle River/Black Bridge Road (at Irrewillipe Road intersection)
  • Tomahawk Creek Road (intersection Princetown Road)
  • Cobden-Lavers Hill Road (intersection Princetown Road)
Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 12/01/2026 09:00 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires) 
  • ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:

  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.location: Barongarook West, Carlisle River, Gellibrand, Irrewillipe, Irrewillipe East, Kawarren
properties.webBody:
This Watch and Act message is being issued for Barongarook West, Carlisle River, Gellibrand, Irrewillipe, Irrewillipe East, Kawarren. 
  • It is strongly recommended you Prepare to Leave. 
  • There is a bushfire at Carlisle River. The bushfire is not yet under control.
  • The bushfire is travelling from Pipeline Road Carlisle River in a north-westerly direction towards Bungador. 
  • There will be noticeable ground and aircraft activity overnight. 
  • This downgraded Watch and Act message replaces the Watch and Act issued at 10:39pm with a more defined polygon area. 
Prepare to Leave immediately. Leave as soon as you are ready, as roads will become busy as people leave.
What you should do:
  • Monitor the situation. Increased wind speed, change in wind direction, smoke or poor visibility can mean the situation is worsening.
  • Protect yourself and your family.
  • If you are not prepared, leave now. Don’t wait until it is too late - leave early. 
  • If you are away from home, do not return.
If you are leaving, pack: 
  • Cash 
  • Clothing for three days 
  • Medicine for three days 
  • Phone and chargers 
  • Toiletries 
  • Important documents 
  • Meaningful items and photos 
  • Pet essentials, including leash and carriers.
Check on your neighbours if it is safe.

Check the VicTraffic website for road closures.

Leave if the situation changes or you feel unsafe. 

Where to go:
  • Friends or family away from the fire. 
  • Consider roads may become busy closer to the time of impact. 
  • Be aware of road closures when you leave.
Impacts in your area: 
The following roads are closed: 
  • Carlisle River/Black Bridge Road (at Irrewillipe Road intersection)
  • Tomahawk Creek Road (intersection Princetown Road)
  • Cobden-Lavers Hill Road (intersection Princetown Road.

Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria. 

The next update is expected by 12/01/2026 09:00 am or as the situation changes. 

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires) 
  • ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV. 
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • For information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Emergency Warning
properties.webBody:
This Emergency Warning is being issued for Bungil, Burrowye, Granya and surrounds. 
  • There is a bushfire 25Km West Of Walwa that is out of control. 
  • Properties within the warning area could be impacted. 
  • Current wind direction is from the south-east towards north-north west.
  • Conditions can become very dangerous and unpredictable. 
  • A relief centre is available at the Wodonga Racing and Exhibition Centre Crn Wilson and Mitchell St Wodonga.
  • Works are occurring to restore essential services.
  • This Emergency Warning replaces the Emergency Warning issued yesterday at 10:00pm.
Leaving immediately is the safest option, before conditions become too dangerous.

Emergency services may not be able to help you if you decide to stay.   
What you should do: 

Travel to: 
  • The home of family or friends that is away from the warning area.
  • When you leave remember to take your pets, medications, a fully charged mobile phone and charger.
In the car: 
  • If you are travelling, do not enter the area. Make a u-turn and travel to safety.
  • Slow down and turn on your headlights. Smoke will make it difficult to see.
If you are unable to leave you should shelter indoors:
  • Close all exterior doors, windows and vents. Turn off cooling systems.
  • You must take shelter before the fire arrives. The extreme heat is likely to kill you well before the flames reach you.
  • Shelter in a room that has two exits, such as a door or window including one directly to the outside. It is important to be able to see outside so you know what is happening with the fire. 
  • If your home catches on fire and the conditions inside become unbearable, you need to get out and go to an area that has already been burnt. 
If you cannot get indoors, other last resort options include:
  • Shelter in the middle of a large open area like a ploughed paddock, football oval or sporting reserve.
  • Get into a large body of water like a dam, lake, river, the ocean or inground pool.
  • Try to protect yourself from the fire's heat.
If you are caught in fire in your car:
  • Park behind a solid structure to block the fire's heat or pull over to cleared area.
  • Try to position the car towards the approaching fire.
  • Turn on your hazard lights and headlights.
  • Close all windows.
  • Turn off the air-conditioning and shut all the air vents.
  • Turn your car engine off.
  • Get down as low as possible below window level and cover up with a pure woollen blanket.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Residents from Burrowye should travel to Albury/Wodonga via NSW roads, which can be accessed at the river crossing on Jingellic Road.  
  • Residents from Thologolong and Granya must travel west along the Murray River Road to Albury/Wodonga or Tallangatta.
  • For information on NSW fires click here
  • Road closures:
  • Granya road between Murray River Road and Murray Valley Highway.
  • Shelley Road between Murray Valley Highway and Guys Forest Road.
  • Check the VicTraffic website (www.traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.
This messages was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 12/01/2026 10:10 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires).
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

The situation can change at any time. You must monitor conditions and be ready to act.

  • Monitor changes to the situation. Increased wind speed, change in wind direction, smoke or poor visibility can indicate the situation is changing. 
  • Enact your fire survival plan. 
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes. 
  • If you have time, check your neighbours to see if they are monitoring conditions. 
  • Protect yourself and your family.
Leave if the situation changes or you feel unsafe. 
Remember to:
  • Take your pets, medications, mobile phone and charger. 
  • Many people have died trying to leave at the last minute during fires. 
  • Travel to the home of family or friends that are away from the warning area.

The situation can change at any time. You must monitor conditions and be ready to act.
What you should do: 
  • Monitor changes to the situation. Increased wind speed, change in wind direction, smoke or poor visibility can indicate the situation is changing. 
  • Have more than one way to get emergency Information. Mobile phone networks, internet service and electricity supply may be disrupted or unavailable. Have back-up ways to receive warnings such as listening to the radio, checking community notice points or following instructions from emergency services on the ground.

This Watch and Act message is being issued for Mitta Valley including Dartmouth, Eskdale, Mitta Mitta, Tallandoon and surrounds. 
  •  It is Not Safe to Return to Mitta Valley including Dartmouth, Eskdale, Mitta Mitta, Tallandoon and surrounds. 
  • There is a bushfire in the Tallangatta Valley. 
  • The bushfire is out of control.
  • Current wind direction is from the south-east towards north-north west.
  • There is a relief centre at Wodonga Racing and Exhibition Centre. 
  • Works are occurring to restore essential services.  
  • This Watch and Act warning replaces the Watch and Act issued at 12:30am.
If you left the warning area, it is Not Safe to Return. Be aware of potential dangerous bushfire and tree hazards.
What you should do:

If you have not already left: 
  • Stay where you are and avoid dangerous bushfire and tree hazards.
  • Check you have enough food, drinking water and medications - if you do not, phone Triple Zero (000) for assistance.
If you have already left: 
  • Do not return to your home until a Safe to Return notification is issued.
  • A relief centre is open at the Wodonga Racing and Exhibition Centre, which allows pets. 
  • Register at a relief centre so your friends, family and authorities can be informed that you are safe.
  • Stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
Impacts in your area:
  • Trees can be extremely dangerous during a bushfire or high winds. Do not stand, park or travel in areas of fire affected trees.
  • For NSW RFS information click here.
  • Check the VicTraffic website (www.traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria. 

The next update is expected by 12/01/2026 11:40 am or as the situation changes. 

Use multiple sources to stay informed:

  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app

  • ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV. 
Accessibility:

properties.name: Emergency Warning
properties.location: Berringama, Bullioh, Koetong, Lucyvale, Shelley, Tallangatta Valley
properties.webBody:
This Emergency Warning is being issued for Berringama, Bullioh, Koetong, Lucyvale, Shelley, Tallangatta Valley and surrounds.

  • There is a bushfire 25Km West Of Walwa that is out of control.
  • Current wind direction is from the south east towards North North West
  • As it is too late to leave the area safely, you must stay close to shelter and monitor conditions throughout the night on VicEmergency website or download the app.
  • Works are occurring to restore essential services.
  • This Emergency Warning replaces the Emergency Warning issued at 10.06pm yesterday.
If you are in danger, you need to act immediately to survive.

The safest option is to stay close to shelter. 
What you should do if you are in danger:

Move indoors: 
  • Protect yourself by wearing long sleeves and trousers, made from pure cotton or wool. Wear leather boots.  
  • Bring your pets inside.  
  • Close all exterior doors, windows and vents and turn off cooling systems. 
  • You must take shelter before the fire arrives. The extreme heat is likely to kill you well before the flames reach you. 
  • Shelter in a room that has two exits, such as a door or window including one directly to the outside. It is important to be able to see outside so you know what is happening with the fire.
If your home catches on fire: 
  • Move away from the rooms that are on fire, closing doors behind you.
  • As soon as the bushfire has passed the house, or conditions inside become unbearable, you need to get out and go to an area that has already been burnt. Staying inside a burning building will almost certainly end in death. 
  • It may still be too hot to remain outside, so you will need to seek shelter in another structure or last resort option.
If you cannot get indoors, last resort options include:
  • Shelter in the middle of a large open area like a ploughed paddock, football oval or sporting reserve.
  • Get into a large body of water like a dam, lake, river, the ocean or inground pool.
  • Try to protect yourself from the fire's heat.
If you are travelling: 
  • If you are travelling, do not enter the warning area. Make a u-turn and travel to safety. 
  • If you are currently driving slow down and turn on your headlights. Smoke will make it difficult to see.
If you are caught in fire in your car: 
  • Park off the road behind a solid structure to block the fire's heat or pull over to cleared area.
  • Try to position the car towards the approaching fire.
  • Turn on your hazard lights and headlights.
  • Close all windows. 
  • Turn off the air-conditioning and shut all the air vents. 
  • Turn your car engine off. 
  • Get down as low as possible below window level and cover up with a pure woollen blanket.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Bushfires can generate extreme heat. Heat will kill you before the fire reaches you. 
  • Trees can be extremely dangerous during a bushfire or high winds. Do not stand, park or travel in areas of fire affected trees.
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 12/01/2026 10:30 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires).
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:

  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Advice is being issued for Longwood, Longwood East. 
  • As of Saturday 10 January 2026, people in Longwood and Longwood East should boil their tap water before consumption. 
  • The Longwood fire has impacted the operations of the Longwood Water Treatment Plant and this has impacted water supply to customers. 
  • Water is being brought into local storage tanks, which is now supplying the town.
  • This Advice message replaces the Community Information issued at 9:40 pm Saturday, 10 January 2026.
If you live or work within Longwood or Longwood East, you must boil tap water before drinking. 
What you should do:  
  • Boil water before drinking it, or drink bottled water.
  • Boil water for food preparation, cleaning fruit and vegetables, making ice and for preparing baby formula.
  • Boil water for brushing teeth. 
To ensure water is safe, you should: 
  • Heat water until a continuous and rapid stream of air-bubbles is produced from the bottom of a pan or kettle (kettles with automatic shut-off switches are suitable). 
  • Allow water to cool before use. 
  • Store water in a clean, closed container for later use. 
  • Be careful when boiling water to prevent scalding or burns.
  • If you are concerned that you may have been affected by contaminated water, contact your doctor or Nurse-on-Call. 
Impacts in your area: 
  • A tanker of treated water that is safe to drink can be accessed between 8am and 4pm daily. Bring containers to fill from the tanker.
  • Bottled water is available 24 hours a day at the Longwood Recreation Reserve.
  • For more information, visit: www.gvwater.vic.gov.au  
This message was issued by Department of Health.

The next update is expected by 16/01/2026 10:00 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter
  • ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:

  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact the National Relay Service and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.webBody:
This Watch and Act message is being issued for Carlisle River, Gellibrand, Irrewillipe.
  • There is a bushfire at Carlisle River that is not yet under control.
  •  The bushfire is travelling from in a north- north-westerly direction.
  • There will be noticeable ground and aircraft activity overnight. 
  • This Watch and Act replaces the Watch and Act issued at 3:04pm. 
The situation can change at any time. You must monitor conditions and be ready to act.
What you should do: 
  • Monitor changes to the situation. Increased wind speed, change in wind direction, smoke or poor visibility can indicate the situation is changing. 
  • Enact your fire survival plan. 
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes. 
  • If you have time, check your neighbours to see if they are monitoring conditions. 
  • Protect yourself and your family.
Leave if the situation changes or you feel unsafe. 
Remember to:
  • Take your pets, medications, mobile phone and charger. 
  • Many people have died trying to leave at the last minute during fires. 
  • Travel to the home of family or friends that are away from the warning area.
  • An Emergency Relief Centre has been setup at the Colac Showgrounds, please enter via the Bruce Street entrance.
  • The Colac Performing Arts and Culture Centre (COPACC) has been setup as an Information Centre and is open during business hours.
Impacts in your area:
The following roads are  closed:
  • Carlisle River/Black Bridge Road (at Irrewillipe Road intersection)
  • Tomahawk Creek Road (intersection Princetown Road)
  • Cobden-Lavers Hill Road (intersection Princetown Road)

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Advice is being issued for the State of Victoria

Bushfire smoke is impacting air quality in many areas across Victoria.

  • Very Poor air quality is currently being experienced in Mallee, Northern Country, North East, and West and South Gippsland forecast districts.
  • Poor air quality is currently being experienced in Central, South West and Wimmera and Fair in North Central and East Gippsland forecast districts.
  • From Monday onwards, the forecast across the state is Poor air quality. 
  • Extreme heat and bushfire smoke are both harmful to health and the effects of heat exposure can have serious consequences for sensitive individuals.
  • Excessive smoke can aggravate existing heart and lung conditions and cause irritated eyes, coughing and wheezing. 
Smoke can affect people's health. Take steps to reduce your exposure and protect the health of yourself and others.
  • Everyone should minimise the time spent in smoky conditions whenever practical to do so.
  • You can self-assess the air quality near you using these tools. Your nose is an excellent smoke detector. If you can smell smoke, take the necessary precautions to protect your health: https://www.epa.vic.gov.au/smoke-and-your-health.
What you can do:
  • Listen to your local emergency radio station.
  • Check the air quality in your area here: https://www.epa.vic.gov.au/check-air-and-water-quality.
  • Stay indoors away from smoke. If you must go outside when it is very smoky, consider wearing a mask (P2 or N95).
  • Close your windows and doors to keep smoke out of your home.
Keep the air inside your home as clean as possible. You can do this by:
  • Closing windows and doors and opening them when air quality improves, using your split system air conditioner or switching other types of air conditioners to recirculate if they have this function, not using evaporative coolers because they bring outdoor air inside.
  • Using an indoor air cleaner, if you have one, that has a high efficiency particle air (HEPA) filter that is the right size for the room.
  • If you think the air in your home is still uncomfortable, consider relocating if it is safe to do so. For example, go to an air-conditioned building like a library or shopping centre. 
  • You may also consider using a P2 or N95 mask but seek advice from your doctor if you have a pre-existing heart or lung condition.
  • People who are sensitive (people with a heart or lung condition, including asthma; people over the age of 65; infants and young children; pregnant women; and people with diabetes) to smoke should actively monitor symptoms and follow their health management plan recommended by their doctor.
  • If you are worried about your symptoms, see your doctor or call Nurse on Call on 1300 606 024.
  • If you or anyone in your care has trouble breathing, chest pain or discomfort, call Triple Zero (000) for an ambulance.
Impacts in your area:
  • Road travel may be hazardous due to low visibility associated with smoke.
  • Signs may be in place to slow traffic. Obey all traffic signs and instructions from fire agency crews near the fires.
  • Environment Protection Authority is monitoring air quality across the state. 
This message was issued by Environment Protection Authority.

The next update is expected by 12/01/2026 08:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact the National Relay Service and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.webBody:
This Watch and Act message is being issued for East Natimuk, Grass Flat, Natimuk, Quantong, Vectis, Vectis East, Vectis South.
  • The fire in the Natimuk, Quantong and Vectis area is now contained. 
  • Firefighters, emergency services and Powercor continue to work on the fire, treatment of fire affected trees and repair of powerlines. 
  • Residents should stay alert for dangerous trees and electrical hazards. 
  • The Wimmera Highway opened at 3pm today, 11th January 2026, for all traffic through Natimuk. 
  • All roads east of the Wimmera River in the Quantong and Vectis area will open from 7pm today, 11th January 2026.
  • Other local roads remain closed due to safety concerns, continue to obey all road signage. 
This Watch and Act message replaces the Watch and Act issued at 3.39pm Sunday 11th January 2026.

    • While the threat is reduced, there is still active fire in the area. The situation can change at any time. You must monitor conditions and be ready to act.
    What you should do:  
    • Monitor changes to the situation, noting there is still active fire in the area.
    • Watch out out for essential services and vehicles working in the area.
    • There are still powerlines down and hazardous trees within the fire ground. 
    • Access to Natimuk township via the Wimmera Highway only.
    • Increased wind speed, change in wind direction, smoke or poor visibility can indicate the situation is changing. 

    Leave if the situation changes or you feel unsafe. Remember to: 
    • Take your pets, medications, mobile phone and charger. 
    • Many people have died trying to leave at the last minute during fires. 
    • Travel to the home of family or friends that are away from the warning area. 
    Impacts in your area: 

    The Wimmera Highway opened through Natimuk at 3pm Sunday 11th January 2026.

    All roads East of the Wimmera River in the Quantong and Vectis area will open from 7pm today, 11th January 2026.

    Some local roads remain closed due to safety concerns. 

    Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.

    A recovery centre will be open at 62 Main Street, Natimuk from Monday 12th January, 10am to 4pm.
    This message was issued by Country Fire Authority.   

    The next update is expected by 12/01/2026 01:00 pm or as the situation changes.

properties.webBody:
This Watch and Act message is being issued for Barkers Creek, Harcourt, Harcourt North, Ravenswood South, Sutton Grange, Walmer. 
  • There is a grassfire that started at Fogartys Gap Road, Ravenswood South that is not yet under control. 
  • The spread of fire has slowed and is not travelling outside the current burn area, but this can change at any time and the situation is still dangerous. You must monitor conditions and be ready to act.
  • It is not safe to return.
  • There were many trees impacted by fire and are considered dangerous until assessment processes are complete. 
  • The fire crossed Calder Highway, impacted Harcourt, Mount Alexander and areas to the east towards Sutton Grange.
  • Smoke may be visible from nearby communities and may be present for the next few days. 
  • A Recovery Hub will open at the Castlemaine Town Hall, 25 Lyttleton Street, on Monday, 12 January 2026. Opening hours will be from 11:00am and 5:00pm. 
  • For affected residents, the Recovery Hub will include a number of agencies and organisations that can assist you through the recovery process including temporary accommodation support. 
  • The Emergency Relief Centres at the Bendigo Showgrounds and Kyneton Sports and Aquatic Centre will close Monday, 12 January 2026, at 9:00am.
  • A copy of the Community Newsletter for 11 January 2026 is available here 
  • A livestream community meeting has been planned for midday Monday, 12 January 2026. This can be accessed from the VicEmergency - Loddon Mallee Facebook page. 
  • This Watch and Act message replaces the Watch & Act issued at 1:46pm on Sunday, 11 January 2026.
  • This will be the last update for the 11 January 2025 unless the situation changes. 
The situation can change at any time. You must monitor conditions and be ready to act.
What you should do:  
  • Monitor changes to the situation. Increased wind speed, change in wind direction, smoke or poor visibility can indicate the situation is changing.

Impacts in your area: 
The following roads are closed:

  • Bendigo-Sutton Grange Road, Elphinstone - from Pollards Road to Grays Road, Sutton Grange

  • Victoria Road, Harcourt - from Calder In-Victoria Ramp Of, Victoria Road, Barkers Creek to Coolstore Road, Harcourt
  • Harmony Way/Pyrenees Highway Intersection, Elphinstone  
  • McIvor Road, Harcourt North - from Harcourt-Sutton Grange Road to Reservoir Road.
We are working on making roads safe before they open.

Check the VicTraffic website (www.traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures. 

  • The fire has impacted communication towers on Mount Alexander which has impacted radio broadcasting and free to air TV. Phoenix FM (106.7) are now providing emergency broadcasting for the ABC.

  • Grassfires can generate extreme heat.
  • Grassfires can start and spread quickly, and are extremely dangerous.  
This message was issued by Country Fire Authority.

This can be accessed from the VicEmergency - Loddon Mallee Facebook page. - This Watch and Act message replaces the Watch & Act issued at 1:46pm on Sunday, 11 January 2026. - This will be the last update for the 11 January 2025 unless the situation changes. properties.name: Emergency Warning
properties.webBody:
This Emergency Warning is being issued for Irrewillipe.

  • There is a bushfire at Carlisle River that is out of control.
  • The bushfire is travelling from Pipeline Road, Carlisle River in a north-westerly direction towards Bungador.   
  • This fire is threatening homes and lives.
  • It is too late to leave the area safely so you must take shelter now.
  • This Emergency Warning replaces the Emergency Warning issued at 10:39pm, Sunday 11 January. 
You are in danger and need to act immediately to survive.

The safest option is to take shelter indoors immediately. It is too late to leave.
What you should do:

Move indoors: 
  • Protect yourself by wearing long sleeves and trousers, made from pure cotton or wool. Wear leather boots.  
  • Bring your pets inside.  
  • Close all exterior doors, windows and vents and turn off cooling systems. 
  • You must take shelter before the fire arrives. The extreme heat is likely to kill you well before the flames reach you. 
  • Shelter in a room that has two exits, such as a door or window including one directly to the outside. It is important to be able to see outside so you know what is happening with the fire.
If your home catches on fire: 
  • Move away from the rooms that are on fire, closing doors behind you.
  • As soon as the bushfire has passed the house, or conditions inside become unbearable, you need to get out and go to an area that has already been burnt. Staying inside a burning building will almost certainly end in death. 
  • It may still be too hot to remain outside, so you will need to seek shelter in another structure or last resort option.
If you cannot get indoors, last resort options include:
  • Shelter in the middle of a large open area like a ploughed paddock, football oval or sporting reserve.
  • Get into a large body of water like a dam, lake, river, the ocean or inground pool.
  • Try to protect yourself from the fire's heat.
If you are travelling: 
  • If you are travelling, do not enter the warning area. Make a u-turn and travel to safety. 
  • If you are currently driving slow down and turn on your headlights. Smoke will make it difficult to see.
If you are caught in fire in your car: 
  • Park off the road behind a solid structure to block the fire's heat or pull over to cleared area.
  • Try to position the car towards the approaching fire.
  • Turn on your hazard lights and headlights.
  • Close all windows. 
  • Turn off the air-conditioning and shut all the air vents. 
  • Turn your car engine off. 
  • Get down as low as possible below window level and cover up with a pure woollen blanket.
Impacts in your area: 
The following roads are closed:
  • Carlisle River/Black Bridge Road (at Irrewillipe Road intersection)
  • Tomahawk Creek Road (intersection Princetown Road)
  • Cobden-Lavers Hill Road (intersection Princetown Road)

This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 12/01/2026 09:00 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires).
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

  •  It is Not Safe to Return to Biggara, Colac Colac, Corryong, Cudgewa, Nariel Valley, Thowgla Valley, Towong, Walwa. 
  • There is a bushfire at 25Km West Of Walwa that is out of control. 
  • Current wind direction is from the south-east towards the north north-west.
  • Conditions can become very dangerous and unpredictable. 
  • A relief centre is available at the Wodonga Racing and Exhibition Centre Cnr Wilson and Mitchell Street Wodonga.
  • Works are occurring to restore essential services. 
  • This replaces the previous Watch and Act message issued at 10:42pm yesterday.
If you left the warning area, it is Not Safe to Return. Be aware of potential dangerous bushfire and tree hazards.
What you should do:

If you have not already left: 
  • Stay where you are and avoid dangerous bushfire and tree hazards.
  • Check you have enough food, drinking water and medications - if you do not, phone Triple Zero (000) for assistance.
If you have already left: 
  • Do not return to your home until a Safe to Return notification is issued.
  • A relief centre is open at the Wodonga Racing and Exhibition Centre.
  • Register at a relief centre so your friends, family and authorities can be informed that you are safe.
  • Stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
Impacts in your area:

  • Murray River Road From Granya Road to Guys Forest Road.
  • The Murray Valley Highway is closed from Cudgewa Valley Road to Old Tallangatta.
  • Shelley Road from Guys Forest Road to Murray Valley Highway.
  • Travel to Albury/Wodonga via NSW roads, which can be accessed at the river crossings at Jinjellic Rd, Tintaldra, Towong and Towong Upper.
  • Trees can fall across roads and cause dangerous driving conditions.
  • Bushfires can generate extreme heat. Heat will kill you before the fire reaches you.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Advice is being issued for Barkers Creek, Castlemaine, Harcourt.
  • As of 11:45am Saturday 10 January, the tap water at Barkers Creek, Harcourt and part of Castlemaine is not safe to drink. 
  • This advice has been issued following the impact of the fires in Harcourt on Friday 9 January 2026. Water services have been unable to safely access a burst water main, which may have caused contaminants to enter the water supply network.
  • This is an updated Advice message that replaces the Advice issued at 5:04 pm yesterday, 10 January 2026.
Tap water is not safe to drink in Harcourt, Barkers Creek and part of Castlemaine. Boiling the tap water will not make it safe. 
What you should do: 
  • Do not drink tap water.
  • You should only drink bottled water. 
  • If you are unsure if the water is safe to drink, you should not drink it.
  • For more information, visit: https://coliban.com.au/interruptions/do-not-drink-advisory-harcourt
It is unsafe to use tap water for: 
  • Food preparation, cleaning food or preparing baby formula. 
  • Cleaning dishes or clothing.
  • Making ice, brushing teeth and preparing beverages.
Maintaining personal hygiene: 
  • It is important to stay clean. 
  • Use hand sanitiser after going to the bathroom and before you consume food. 
  • Use disposable baby wipe products that are not soap based without water to clean yourself. 
Impacts in your area: 
  • All residents are asked to not drink tap water until further notice
This message was issued by Department of Health.  

The next update is expected by 12/01/2026 07:30 pm or as the situation changes.   

Use multiple sources to stay informed:  
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter 
  • ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.    
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.  
  • For information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact the National Relay Service and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

  • Monitor changes to the situation. Increased wind speed, change in wind direction, smoke or poor visibility can indicate the situation is changing. 
  • Enact your fire survival plan. 
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes. 
  • If you have time, check your neighbours to see if they are monitoring conditions. 
  • Protect yourself and your family.
Leave if the situation changes or you feel unsafe. 
Remember to:
  • Take your pets, medications, mobile phone and charger. 
  • Many people have died trying to leave at the last minute during fires. 
  • Travel to the home of family or friends that are away from the warning area.
Impacts in your area:

Road Closures:

Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.


This message was issued by Country Fire Authority.

The next update is expected by 12/01/2026 02:40 pm or as the situation changes.

Community Meeting:

A community meeting will be held at the following location:
Euroa Cinema
Monday 12th Jan, 2026
5pm
1B Bury St, Euroa

If safe to do so feel free to attend the meeting to gain further information about the current fire situation and the supports and services that may be available to you.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires) 
  • ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • For information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for Cobram, Katamatite, Katunga, Muckatah, Naring, Yarroweyah, Yarroweyah South.
  • There is a grassfire at Yarroweyah that is contained.
  • This Advice message replaces the Advice message - Stay Informed issued at 12:31 pm on 10th January. 
  • There is currently no threat to you, but you should stay informed and monitor conditions.
  • Benalla - Tocumwal Road remains closed at this stage. 

What you should do: 
  • Keep the roads clear as firefighters and emergency services are still operating in the area.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Smoke may be visible from nearby communities and roads. 
  • Significant works are being undertaken along the Benalla / Tocumwal Road to remove fire impacted hazardous trees along the roadside.
  • CFA, Forest Fire Management vehicles and Excavators are working in the area, constantly stopping. Avoid travelling in and around the area. 
  • Road closures in place across the area (local council roads) are being reviewed today, please check the VicTraffic website (https://traffic.transport.vic.gov.au/) for the latest up to date information. 
This message was issued by Country Fire Authority.

The next update is expected by 12/01/2026 12:30 pm or as the situation changes.

  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226

  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

The Threat is Reduced following the bushfire at 2km North of Cabbage Tree Creek. 
  • The bushfire at Cabbage Tree Creek near the Princes Highway is now under control.
  • Forest fire fighters will continue to monitor the situation and respond if required.
  • This Advice message replaces the Advice issued at 7.30 pm, 8/01/2026.
People located within the area are now able to resume normal activities.
Impacts in your area:
  • Emergency services will remain in the area. 
  • Smoke may be visible from this and other bushfires in the landscape from nearby communities and roads. 
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.  

This will be the final message issued for this fire. 

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
